utterances: Then, you know, we'll make sure that they have a blanket if they're cold, if they're hungry, we will get them something to eat, but we don't want to promise them anything that we can't promise.
So we don't give too much information until we know the facts.
Are the kids being brought in with anything to keep them going?
Do they have clothes?
Do they have anything with them?
The ones that I have seen, no, they're not brought in with clothes, or backpacks, or things like that.
Maybe medications or medical information is shared with us, but not necessarily belongings.
Hmm.
Are you starting to see a pattern in terms of the background of the families, what's going on at home?
We have a lot of instances where, you know, the parents and the child have been fighting, and this has been going on for a number of years.
Issues of truancy, runaway, or mental-health diagnoses.
I was reading some descriptions of these cases in the Omaha World-Herald, and it did seem that a number of these children were deeply, deeply troubled, severe psychiatric problems.
Violence toward their caregiver...
Mm-hmm.
And one man, an uncle who left his 15-year-old nephew said, I'm done beating my head against the wall.
He's been trying to get help for the kid, trying a lot of different avenues apparently, and none of them worked.
Right.
This was the last resort.
Yeah.
I know, and parents and guardians are very frustrated, and feel like they don't know where to turn, or this is their last resort for them.
So part of our goal as social workers is to talk to them about options, and many of these families didn't know about a lot of the agencies that are available out there.
I know social workers see a lot of really, tough stuff all the time.
But I just imagine that you and your co-workers at the hospital must be pretty torn apart, by what you're seeing with these cases.
The timetable does get highly individualized for kids, and there's a lot of variability in neural developments during adolescence.
We are.
You know, we get into this field, because we love what we do and we can't imagine doing anything else.

But it is emotionally taxing and you know, especially if you do work in an emergency room, you have so many cases going on, you know, you can have patients dying in one room or you know, a gunshot wound or another child - a child abuse is going on, or maybe a sexual assault, and then you can have a potential safe haven at the same time.
So, we've really been challenged to give everything that we have and then more, when we feel like we don't have anything else to give.
Well, Courtney Anderson, thanks very much for talking with us.
You're welcome.
Thank you.
Courtney Anderson is a social worker at Immanuel Medical Center in Omaha, Nebraska.
She says of the eight children brought to the hospital under the safe haven law, five have become wards of the state.
Three ultimately ended up going home with their parents.
Coming up, a downshift in the housing market.
First, the CEO of RadioShack has resigned after revelations that his resume was inaccurate, as NPR's Ted Robbins reports.
David Edmonson's resume listed a bachelor's degree in psychology, and a diploma in theology, from Pacific Coast Baptist College, in California.
But the school said it never offered degrees in psychology, and that Edmonson only completed two semesters.
RadioShack board chairman Leonard Roberts told reporters in a conference call that the company didn't fully check when Edmonson was hired as an executive in 1994.
Of course, we checked references, we checked criminal records, we checked credit ratings, and we had all that on Mr. Edmonson.
But we weren't checking academic credentials.
We basically assumed they were correct.
Roberts said hiring policies have been changed.
After the Fort Worth Star Telegram broke the news last week, RadioShack said it would launch an investigation.
But since then, pressure mounted on Edmonson to resign.
The company says the decision was mutual.
The 46-year-old Edmonson is also scheduled to stand trial in Fort Worth on drunk-driving charges.
RadioShack is struggling financially.
Last week, it said fourth quarter earnings fell 62 percent, and it announced plans to close 400 to 700 of its nearly 7,000 stores.
Ted Robbins, NPR News.
Most Americans encountered Chinese cuisine and their local Chinatown or strip mall.
For Commentator Jay Keyser, Chinese food played a special role in his mother's life as she grew old.
It affected how she related to him and to eating.
When my father died, my mother moved to a much sought-after assisted living facility.
Once a week I took her food shopping.
Mom rarely ate in the communal dining room.
I didn't blame her.
The yellow walls were windowless.
A television set was strategically mounted overhead for those who ate alone.
It was always on.
Shopping never took long.
Mom didn't need much.
There was always time for us to have lunch and avoid the communal dining room.
Her favorite was a Chinese restaurant - that was fine with me.
I was proud of my knowledge of Chinese cuisine.
I wanted to show it off for her.
It didn't work out that way.
Our weekly lunches turned into weekly skirmishes.
Why not try the tofu stuffed with shrimp, I would suggest.
I said chicken chow mein, she would answer stubbornly.
Something had changed.
Mom wasn't the always so mono-palated.
There was a time, when no fresh fish or good red herring escaped her hungry eye.
All you ever order now is chicken chow mein, I protested.
Try something different for once.
The scallion pancakes or maybe the stir fried sea cucumbers.
Uhhg, she would say.
Just order me chicken chow mein, please.
These weekly tussles infuriated me.
Why couldn't she take my advice just once and order something different.
I tried stratagems.
I would order something special for myself, say fish head cooked at a clay pot or tripe with cilantro.
Then, I would offer her some.
Take it away, she would say, deflecting my chopsticks with her speckled hand.
The tripe fell on the table top, more often, the floor.
She ate her chicken chow mein with all the grace of someone who had just crawled out of the dessert.
Throughout the meal, she would complain about the food they served in the communal dinning room of the much sought after assisted-living facility.
After a while, it dawned on me - what was going on.
My mother was not fighting me,
she was fighting dependency.
Her weekly choice of the same, darned dish, staked out her claim to being an independent eater.
She was not about to rely on a communal anything.
Finally, I stopped fighting.
I ordered whatever I wanted for myself.
She ordered chicken chow mein.
One day, when the weight that brought me an order of lion's head pork meatballs in a clay pot, and my mother, a heaping plate of chicken chow mein, I said, mom, do you mind if I have a taste?
Go ahead, she said, pushing the plate toward me.
I gathered a mouthful between my chopsticks.
Hey, I said.
I was genuinely surprised, this is good.
Mom didn't say a word.
She just went on eating.
The next week, she died suddenly, a heart attack that followed an emergency operation on a broken hip.
The day after I buried her, I went back to the Chinese restaurant for lunch.
The waiter said the special was stir fried duck tongue with baby chives.
I said, I'll have the chicken chow mein.
Jay Keyser is a Professor Emeritus of Linguistics at MIT and an avid visitor to his local Chinese restaurant.
(Soundbite of music)

For last week's homework assignment, I asked you to send me a recording of you singing or playing the song ""Deck the Halls."" And you've got one more week to get them in because next week, we'll be combining those performances from all over the country into one big national caroling party.
So it will go like this.
Let's say there's a theremin player in one state.
(Soundbite of song, ""Deck the Halls"")
And someone banging on a kitchen sink in another.
(Soundbite of song, ""Deck the Halls"")
Apparently the difference here is that ""Brokeback Mountain"" includes a bit of sex, and the worry is that the recruiting-age young men who go see Gyllenhaal in ""Jarhead"" will be freaked.

But this generation of young people has seen vastly more out gays and lesbians than their parents did, and I'm not talking about frothy characters like the men of ""Will & Grace."" I'm talking about openly gay kids in high school or kids who decide they're gay for a while and then not.
Without these people, the dance music industry, Friendster and Jerry Springer wouldn't exist.
For all the talk of controversy, the film's actually tame.
The most lyrical passages of Annie Proulx's story and key moments of dialogue are gone, replaced by gorgeous long shots of Western scenery that look like outtakes from an IMAX film about clouds.
Brokeback Mountain"" will or won't be a box office success, it will or won't win Oscars, but I guarantee you the actors will continue to work.
The larger question is whether Hollywood will produce real gay and straight roles for actors from all backgrounds and create a cinema that looks more like life.
Mark Mobley is a writer living in Athens, Georgia.
It's 22 minutes before the hour.

Today a rocket is scheduled to lift off from Cape Canaveral carrying an invention that to those of us who are laymen just sounds pretty amazing - an example of the living quarters people may someday use in space.
It's an inflatable module that will be attached to the International Space Station.
NPR's Joe Palca has been introducing us to innovative solutions to old problems in his series, Joe's Big Idea, and today, the past and future of living in space.
In the mid-1990s, NASA was trying to figure out how to get astronauts to Mars without the crew going crazy living in a tiny capsule for months on end.
Chris Kennedy was a NASA engineer working on the problem.
It essentially boiled down to this - how do you pack a large living structure in a small rocket cargo space?
The answer?
Inflatables.
Well, there are several advantages for inflatable habitats.
One is you can package it in a smaller volume...
...And then expand it once you get into space.
Now, the inflatable is not like a balloon.
Folded up, it looks just like a cylinder.
Expanded, it grows upward and outward so it looks more like a watermelon.
It's made of multiple layers of Kevlar and other materials resistant to micrometeorites.
And even though it's inflated, Kennedy says you shouldn't think of as squishy.
It's very rigid.
Once you get even a partial pressure to it, it's extremely hard - as hard as aluminum.
But as enthusiastic as some at NASA were for this new approach to building space habitats, Congress wasn't sufficiently impressed, and in 2000, legislators told NASA to kill the program.
Enter billionaire Robert Bigelow, a man who made his fortune in budget hotels.
He saw a future for inflatable space habitats, maybe even space hotels - space tourists got to stay somewhere.
He got the rights to NASA's inflatable technology and created Bigelow Aerospace.

After more than a decade of development, the company has produced BEAM, the Bigelow Expandable Activity Module, and NASA has agreed to attach it to the International Space Station and see how it performs.
Folded up, BEAM is about six by six feet.
Inflated, it's about 12 feet by 10 feet, maybe the size of a small RV.
Jason Crusan is in charge of BEAM for NASA.
He says when it arrives at the station...
...We'll use the robotic arm to remove the BEAM module and actually plug it into it's home onboard the Space Station.
Once it's securely attached, astronauts will start to inflate it.
